history.content:
CS 195 would be a good class to take as well. Pretty easy course and teaches you about the ethics behind CS and the industry.   This does not fulfill this requirement -Nicole 

----------

Engineering 45 (3 units) would be a good one as well if you want to gain some introductory exposure to material science.

----------

E25 teaches visualization, sketching, and 2D cad, but it's a lot of work for a 2 unit class (it was like a 61B vs Math 54 type discrepancy the first semester it was taught) and it's not particularly useful in of itself for anything else. I guess it's good for reading engineering drawings if you think you'll be doing any of that in the future.

E26 teaches 3D CAD and design which is super useful for start-uppy things, design, making, etc. It's super easy if you've had any previous exposure to CAD (such as E25), but it can be pretty hard at the beginning if you don't. They don't really teach good workflow and cad strategies, nor do they teach you how to navigate the program, so you're expected to learn it on your own during the homework, which can be a lot of work early in the semester.

E27 is a great class (esp with Taylor) and goes through a broad survey of manufacturing processes and methods, as well as going more in depth on drawings than E25. It was the easiest for me out of the three, and I did the best in it, but it might be harder without E25.

Also, what about the EECS 151 Labs? They're 2 units and don't look like they require EECS 151. And what about the CS9 series?

CS 195 would be a good class to take as well. Pretty easy course and teaches you about the ethics behind CS and the industry.

----------

Engineering 45 (3 units) would be a good one as well if you want to gain some introductory exposure to material science.

----------

E25 teaches visualization, sketching, and 2D cad, but it's a lot of work for a 2 unit class (it was like a 61B vs Math 54 type discrepancy the first semester it was taught) and it's not particularly useful in of itself for anything else. I guess it's good for reading engineering drawings if you think you'll be doing any of that in the future.

E26 teaches 3D CAD and design which is super useful for start-uppy things, design, making, etc. It's super easy if you've had any previous exposure to CAD (such as E25), but it can be pretty hard at the beginning if you don't. They don't really teach good workflow and cad strategies, nor do they teach you how to navigate the program, so you're expected to learn it on your own during the homework, which can be a lot of work early in the semester.

E27 is a great class (esp with Taylor) and goes through a broad survey of manufacturing processes and methods, as well as going more in depth on drawings than E25. It was the easiest for me out of the three, and I did the best in it, but it might be harder without E25.

Also, what about the EECS 151 Labs? They're 2 units and don't look like they require EECS 151. And what about the CS9 series?

CS 195 would be a good class to take as well. Pretty easy course and teaches you about the ethics behind CS and the industry.

----------

Engineering 45 (3 units) would be a good one as well if you want to gain some introductory exposure to material science.

children.subject: 195 does not count towards this tech unit requirement
That is what I thought, thank you very much!
CS9 are P/NP so they don't count but this was very very helpful, thank you!!!

history.content:
Although you enroll in EECS 151/251A lecture and lab separately, it is recommended to take them together, or at least first take the lecture before the lab.

As long as CivEng 88 is letter graded, it can be applied toward the 45 units: 

6-Students must complete a minimum of 45 units of engineering coursework. Technical electives and the 45 units of engineering courses cannot include: any course taken on a P/NP basis; courses numbered 24, 39, 84; BioE 100; ChemE 185; CS C79, 195, H195; Des Inv courses except (Des Inv 15, 22, 90E, 190E); Engin 125, 157AC, 180; IEOR 95, 172, 185, 186, 190 series, 191, 192, 195; ME 191AC, 190K, 191K. (Source)

I have 1 more engineering unit to consider and I don't have space in my schedule to take another 4 unit technical class, so does anyone have suggestions for low workload engineering classes that fulfill this requirement?

I have considered:

Engineering 25 and 26 (2 units)

Engineering 120 (3 units)

Civeng 88 (not sure if this fulfills the requirement) (2 units)
history.subject: 1-3 Unit Classes to fulfill EECS Engineering units requirement
